metadata.note: This is the canonical result using the original intended threshold τ=0.1. Previous results used τ=0.25 (code drift), which showed super-linear scaling (β=1.45).

hypothesis: Bit-cost scales sub-linearly with image size: B(N) ~ N^beta where beta < 1
null_hypothesis: Bit-cost scales linearly or super-linearly with image size (beta >= 1)

power_law_fit.interpretation: Excellent fit; bits scale sub-linearly with image size

statistical_test.verdict: STRONGLY SUPPORTED - Null hypothesis rejected with p < 0.0001

interpretation: At the conservative threshold τ=0.1, CPPN sample efficiency improves sub-linearly with image size. This means larger images require proportionally fewer bits to reach the threshold, validating the original hypothesis.

related_experiments.RES-036: Extended this scaling analysis to more sizes (8, 12, 16, 24, 32, 48) and found same pattern
related_experiments.RES-069: Found metric scale-dependence issue (edge gate hardcoded for 32×32); fixed with normalized metric v2

paper_usage.claim: At 32×32 resolution with τ=0.1, CPPN requires ~2 bits while uniform requires >72 bits (10²¹× speedup)
paper_usage.validation: CONFIRMED - At size 32, bits = 1.16 ≈ 2 bits (confirms order-of-magnitude claim)

revision_notes: This result uses τ=0.1 (original intended threshold) not τ=0.25 (code drift)
Previous results (τ=0.25) showed β=1.45 (super-linear) due to threshold mismatch
Specify τ=0.1 in Methods section of paper
Add footnote: 'Bits-to-threshold exhibits threshold-dependent scaling: τ=0.1 → β≈0.80, τ=0.25 → β≈1.45'
Update Section 6.2 Limitations to discuss threshold regime dependence
